title: Quotation of the Day: Non-Cheating Champions Gear Up for the Season
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 16, 2020.
content: “Somebody’s got to say the word over there: cheated. That’s important to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kanika Shah, Vikram Singh
description: The couple met 20 years ago through a mutual friend and reconnected in 2017 through a dating app.
content: Kanika Shah and Vikram Singh are to be married Feb. 16 at the Taglyan Complex, an events space in Los Angeles. Pandit Dilip J. Bhatt is to perform a traditional Hindu ceremony at the Taglyan Complex. On Feb. 15, the couple took part in a Sikh ceremony that was held at the Hollywood Sikh Temple.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Noah Mamis, Jason Ziplow
description: The couple met in 2015 on OkCupid.
content: Noah Alexander Mamis and Dr. Jason Lee Ziplow are to be married Feb. 16 at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in Manhattan. Rabbi Stuart W. Gershon is to officiate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Outlander’ and ‘Last Week Tonight’
description: So many premieres, so little time: “Outlander” returns to Starz, the documentary series “Slow Burn” debuts on Epix and John Oliver is back on HBO.
content: OUTLANDER 8 p.m. on Starz. The fifth season of this historical time-travel drama, adapted from Diana Gabaldon’s novels, picks up in the aftermath of Brianna (Sophie Skelton) and Roger’s (Richard Rankin) wedding celebrations. Jamie (Sam Heughan) considers how to move forward after he is ordered to gather a militia to bring down the Regulators and kill their leader, the fugitive Murtagh (Duncan Lacroix), who just happens to be his godfather. Brianna revisits a traumatic moment after hearing some shocking news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for $450,000 or Less
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Officer Pointed Gun at Black College Student’s Head, Lawsuit Says
description: Jaylan Butler, a swimmer at Eastern Illinois University, said he was unlawfully searched and held at gunpoint by officers during a bus stop with his team last year.
content: Jaylan Butler and his Eastern Illinois University swim teammates were returning from a championship tournament last year in Sioux Falls, S.D., when their bus driver pulled off Interstate 80 near a rest stop in East Moline, Ill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rate of New Fatalities Drops in China
description: China’s National Health Commission on Monday reported 2,048 new cases of coronavirus infections and 105 new deaths over the previous 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Steinberg
title: Learning to Balance Profit With a Social Mission
description: More entrepreneurs are pursuing social or environmental goals, but they still have to find a successful product or service to sell.
content: HONESDALE, Pa. — Ask Jeff Abella if he likes coffee, and he’ll say yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Farah Stockman and Thomas Fuller
title: ‘Are You Sick?’ For Asian-Americans, a Sneeze Brings Suspicion
description: Though there are only a few known cases in the U.S., the coronavirus outbreak has left some Asian-Americans feeling an unsettling level of public scrutiny.
content: CHICAGO — Strings of lanterns in festive red and gold swayed high above the streets in Chicago’s Chinatown, but few people strolled the sidewalks on a recent afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Silicon Valley Heads to Europe, Nervous About New Rules
description: Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg and Google’s Sundar Pichai have journeyed to Brussels as the European Union drafts regulation for A.I. and the digital economy.
content: LONDON — First came Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google’s parent company, Alphabet. Then Apple’s senior vice president for artificial intelligence, John Giannandrea, showed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Jonathan Martin
title: The Next Hurdle for Bernie Sanders: Nevada’s Top Union Dislikes ‘Medicare for All’
description: His Democratic rivals are trying to capitalize.
content: LAS VEGAS — Senator Bernie Sanders is a longtime supporter of “Medicare for all.” “I wrote the damn bill,” he said on a debate stage last summer, and his support for universal health care has helped propel him to the front of the 2020 Democratic field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and David McCabe
title: Trump Effort to Keep U.S. Tech Out of China Alarms American Firms
description: The administration wants to protect national security by restricting the flow of technology to China. But technology companies worry it could undermine them instead.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s push to prevent China from dominating the market for advanced technologies has put it on a collision course with the same American companies it wants to protect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Young Somalis Step in Where Government Fails
description: In a country that has endured three decades of chaos — from extremist attacks and environmental crises — the responders, medics, road-builders and educators are often not government workers, but young volunteers.
content: MOGADISHU, Somalia — She had just finished battling the floods, and then the bomb went off.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Brian Noviski, Paul Harris
description: The couple were introduced in 2012 through mutual friends at the Toronto International Film Festival.
content: Brian Neil Noviski and Paul Elliott Harris are to be married Feb. 16 at Alo, a restaurant in Toronto. Sandra L. Ruch, a registered officiant with the province of Ontario, is to officiate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Lucas
title: One Pot, One Meal: Curating a Special Set of Simple Recipes
description: NYT Cooking editors collected 24 recipes for dishes cooked in one vessel. Because who wants to wash more dishes?
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 16, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 16, 2020.
content: An article on Page 4 about whether to stick with TV shows with mediocre pilots describes incorrectly the online availability of the series “Murder, She Wrote.” The first five seasons were streaming on Amazon Prime Video at the time of publication; it was not unavailable on all three so-called Big 3 streamers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lorin Eleni Gill and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A Hunt for Clues in Hawaii After a Tourist Couple Falls Ill With Coronavirus
description: A couple visiting Waikiki Beach tested positive for the virus after returning to Japan. Public health officials are investigating to see if anyone else was exposed.
content: HONOLULU — Chantelle Pajarillo had settled into a resort on Hawaii’s famous Waikiki Beach, hoping for a peaceful long weekend away from work and school with her family. The peaceful part came to an end as soon as she turned on the television set Friday night and learned that a Japanese couple who had been staying at the same hotel had fallen ill with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Doctor’s Suicide Note Has Parents Asking: Was My Child Really Vaccinated?
description: Before he died, Van Koinis, an Illinois pediatrician, wrote of his regrets about immunizations. The authorities are now investigating whether he had been misleading patients.
content: An Illinois pediatrician’s mysterious suicide note has raised troubling questions about the immunization records of children in the Chicago-area community he served for years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Simone Rocha :Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Simone Rocha: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Simone Rocha: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: ‘Così’ at the Met, as Mild as a Coney Island Morning
description: Though superbly cast, a staging of Mozart’s dark classic updated to the 1950s goes for starry skies, not stark suffering.
content: Pity the Metropolitan Opera’s social media team, forced on Valentine’s Day to promote Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” on Instagram as an “enchanting romantic comedy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Bread for a Reuben Sandwich
description: Sally Hoelscher makes her debut on Presidents’ Day.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — A crossword that celebrates a holiday is nothing new. We’ve solved puzzles that celebrate Halloween, Valentine’s Day, Christmas and Hanukkah. We’ve even solved Presidents’ Day-themed puzzles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Crazy Mascots Flooded Japan. Can This Grouchy Boar Survive?
description: The country’s fading towns saw the colorful characters as a way to lure tourists and investment. With few success stories, many are being quietly killed off.
content: NAGANO, Japan — The mayor of Misato, a remote village of 4,700 people in rugged western Japan, laid down an ultimatum early last year: The local mascot character, Misabo, must prove his worth. Or else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make a classic beef Stroganoff — or go wild, and treat yourself to an outrageously rich meatloaf Stroganoff!
content: Good morning. I have a piece in The New York Times Magazine this week, a manifesto about how cooking dinner can change your life. It’s adapted from my new book, “See You on Sunday: A Cookbook for Family and Friends,” which I hope you’ll see stacked next to the cat in the front window of your local independent bookstore on Tuesday, which is publication day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Coronavirus, Bushfires, Sri Lanka
content: The number of reported coronavirus cases stood at more than 68,500, with nearly 1,700 deaths, including a man in Taiwan with no history of travel to mainland China. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: Unloved by Trump, NPR Carries On
description: Donations to the public broadcaster went up sharply after the president said it was “a very good question” to ask why it still existed.
content: First President Trump questioned the existence of National Public Radio in a tweet. Then, as part of the annual budget request released last Monday, he recommended slashing federal funding to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the body that distributes taxpayer dollars to NPR and other public media outlets, to $0 by 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock, Sui-Lee Wee and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Coronavirus Infection Found After Cruise Ship Passengers Disperse
description: Amid assurances that the Westerdam was disease free, hundreds of people disembarked in Cambodia and headed for airports. One was later found to be infected.
content: The cruise ship had been shunned at port after port for fear it might carry the coronavirus, but when the Westerdam arrived in Cambodia on Thursday, the prime minister greeted its passengers with flowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: ‘We Changed Harvard’: The Story of 18 Black Students
description: Kent Garrett, who with Jeanne Ellsworth wrote “The Last Negroes at Harvard,” talks about how they found the African-American men of the class of 1963.
content: When Kent Garrett enrolled as a freshman at Harvard in 1959, he did so with 17 other African-Americans, the largest number of black students in one class at the school up to that time. “We were headed for a campus,” he writes in “The Last Negroes at Harvard,” “that in the 1920s barred Negroes from the dormitories and had a branch of the Ku Klux Klan.” Garrett went on to a career in TV news production. After retirement, he became interested in the fates of those who had been in his class, who saw the 1950s give way to the unrest and transformative changes of the following decade. With his partner and co-author, Jeanne Ellsworth, Garrett did extensive traveling to meet up with the alumni and learn what had happened to them in all the years since they were together on campus. The book is written in Garrett’s first-person voice for clarity, but he stresses in the introduction that “there is hardly a word or idea here that isn’t the product of our collaboration.” Below, Garrett talks about confirming the number of his classmates, a filmmaker and friend who inspired him and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain Battered as ‘Weather Bomb’ Brings Landslides and Travel Chaos
description: Fast on the heels of another big storm, Dennis has caused flooding and misery for the second straight weekend.
content: LONDON — Britain has been battered by severe weather for the second consecutive weekend, prompting an official warning on Sunday that lives were at risk as streets became flooded, mud flowed, rail tracks were submerged and dozens of flights were canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Austin Ramzy
title: U.S. Passengers Evacuate Quarantined Cruise Ship in Japan
description: Americans boarded two flights chartered by the State Department and headed to the United States after the number of coronavirus cases aboard the Diamond Princess grew to 355.
content: TOKYO — American passengers evacuated a cruise ship that had been quarantined for more than a week in the Japanese port city of Yokohama, after hundreds of people on board fell ill with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Democrats Plan to Highlight Health Care and Jobs Over Investigating Trump
description: With impeachment behind them and an eye on November, Democrats appear to have decided that focusing on President Trump’s norm-shattering words and deeds only elevates him.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats, recovering from their failed push to remove President Trump from office, are making a sharp pivot to talking about health care and economic issues, turning away from their investigations of the president as they focus on preserving their majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: This Week in Business: Amazon Is Coming for Trump
description: Plus, Bloomberg floods the internet with ads — and the campaign trail with cash.
content: I hope your Valentine’s Day was especially good this year. Americans were forecast to break records with their gifting on Friday, spending an average of $196.31 on their loved ones — a 21 percent increase from last year’s average of $161.96, according to the National Retail Federation. Thanks, and you’re welcome, economy! Here’s the rest of the week’s top news in business and tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Steve Lohr
title: Trump Administration Considering Halting Sales of Aircraft Parts to China
description: The review is part of a broader effort to restrict the flow of sensitive technology to China.
content: The Trump administration is considering halting to China the sale of an aircraft engine produced in part by General Electric, two people familiar with the discussions said, part of a broader effort to limit the flow of technology there that could one day give Beijing an economic and security edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: As Homelessness Plagues Los Angeles, Success Comes for Veterans
description: In California’s biggest city, a nearly 400-acre campus with new housing represents one of the country’s most ambitious plans to address veteran homelessness.
content: LOS ANGELES — For nearly two decades, Bobby Shriver, the onetime mayor of nearby Santa Monica, would look at the sprawling Department of Veterans Affairs complex in the upscale neighborhood on the west side of Los Angeles and wonder why it could not house some of the homeless veterans who had been living in squalor in his beachside city for a generation. Many of the politicians, federal officials and wealthy residents he lobbied greeted the idea with derision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: New Paris Mayoral Contender Is Named After Scandal Topples Macron Ally
description: Health Minister Agnes Buzyn joins the race, while a Russian performance artist gets scrutiny in a leak of explicit videos.
content: PARIS — The French health minister, Agnes Buzyn, was named as a new candidate for mayor of Paris on Sunday, after a scramble to replace the original contender, who abruptly withdrew after a leak of sex videos on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jacqueline Penn, Alexander Deutsch
description: The couple met four years ago through the dating app Hinge.
content: Dr. Jacqueline Hannah Penn and Alexander Jared Deutsch are to be married Feb. 16 at the Rainbow Room in New York. Rabbi Maurice Salth is to officiate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elle O’Sullivan, Peter Bradt
description: She won 10 out of 10 games of Skee-Ball on their first date.
content: Ellen Clare O’Sullivan and Peter Ryan Bradt were married Feb. 15 at the Bel Air Bay Club, an events space in Los Angeles. Katherine Hudson, a Universal Life minister and a maternal aunt of the groom, officiated, with Catherine Frugé Starghill, a maternal aunt of the bride, taking part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Tony Fernandez, Stylish All-Star Shortstop, Is Dead at 57
description: He helped the Blue Jays win a World Series in 1993 and played for the Yankees and the Mets. He had waited years for a new kidney.
content: Tony Fernandez, a stylish shortstop who made five All-Star teams during his 17 seasons in the major leagues and helped the Toronto Blue Jays win the 1993 World Series, died on Sunday in Weston, Fla. He was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: Plant-Based Meat Has Roots in the 1970s
description: Americans looking to cut back on meat are following a movement forged by a groundbreaking book, ‘Diet for a Small Planet.’
content: Even as Americans mass in cities and their suburbs, the range-roaming cowboy has endured as a national symbol, along with the cholesterol-laden diet he represents: heavy on steaks, hamburgers, sausages and the like. What if that iconic image were replaced someday by, say, a technician in a lab coat producing a facsimile of a traditional burger, one made from plants and not animals?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Victoria Beckham: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Victoria Beckham: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Victoria Beckham: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Retro Report
title: Meatless Burgers Are on Trend. Eating to Save the World Has a Long History.
description: Plant-based meats may be high tech, but the ideas behind them have been around for decades.
content: Plant-based meats may be high tech, but the ideas behind them have been around for decades.

title: Meatless Burgers Are on Trend. Eating to Save the World Has a Long History.
description: Plant-based meats may be high tech, but the ideas behind them have been around for decades.

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: Plant-Based Meat Has Roots in the 1970s
description: Americans looking to cut back on meat are following a movement forged by a groundbreaking book, ‘Diet for a Small Planet.’
content: Even as Americans mass in cities and their suburbs, the range-roaming cowboy has endured as a national symbol, along with the cholesterol-laden diet he represents: heavy on steaks, hamburgers, sausages and the like. What if that iconic image were replaced someday by, say, a technician in a lab coat producing a facsimile of a traditional burger, one made from plants and not animals?

author: By Julie Bosman and Todd Heisler
title: Black Families Came to Chicago by the Thousands. Why Are They Leaving?
description: There is an exodus of African-Americans from Chicago. Hardis White, 78, is one of those who left, and three generations of his family wrestled with staying or going.
content: HILLSIDE, Ill. — Hardis White, 78, could hardly wait to break out of suburbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Stephen Reiss
title: Coronavirus, Michael Bloomberg, Kobe Bryant: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Highly Secretive Iranian Rebels Are Holed Up in Albania. They Gave Us a Tour.
description: Depending on whom you ask, the People’s Jihadists are Iran’s government-in-waiting or a duplicitous terrorist cult that forbids sexual thoughts. What are they doing in Albania?
content: MANEZ, Albania — In a valley in the Albanian countryside, a group of celibate Iranian dissidents have built a vast and tightly guarded barracks that few outsiders have ever entered.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Danielle Serbin, Yuvaraj Sivalingam
description: The couple met at a meeting of the Orange County Young Democrats in Santa Ana.
content: Danielle Elise Serbin and Yuvaraj Sivalingam are to be married Feb. 16 at the Ebell Club in Long Beach, Calif. Rabbi Richard Steinberg is to officiate, with Cantor Arie Shikler to take part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. Expects to Lose ‘Hundreds of Millions’ From China Rift, Silver Says
description: Commissioner Adam Silver said the business loss from not being on the air in China was “substantial” but that the league accepted the consequences of its values.
content: CHICAGO — N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said on Saturday that the league will likely lose “hundreds of millions of dollars” because of a rift with the Chinese government that has affected sponsorships and television revenue but that he believed there would “be a return to normalcy fairly soon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Conti
title: It’s an Investment, Yes. But for One Day, It’s a Time Machine.
description: On opening day of baseball-card season, before the speculators and brokers take over, collectors get to feel like kids again.
content: Fred Baumann stepped outside to look for the truck. It was nearing noon, which meant that collectors across the city would soon be heading to the Upper East Side on their lunch breaks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Adrienne McGill, Brian Adams
description: The couple met at a Halloween party in 2008.
content: Adrienne Melissa McGill and Brian Justin Adams were married Feb. 15 at Los Poblanos Historic Inn and Organic Farm in Albuquerque. William Lang, the former chief judge of New Mexico’s Second Judicial District Court in Albuquerque, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Israel Accuses Hamas of ‘Catfishing’ Soldiers to Plant Malware
description: The Israeli military said the militant group in Gaza tried to dupe its troops by posing as women seeking romance. Hamas said Israel hacked one of its Telegram groups and posted doctored photos.
content: JERUSALEM — Hamas and Israel still exchange fire with sporadic rocket attacks and airstrikes in their long-running military standoff along the Gaza border, but the two sides are also engaged in something of an arms race on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Bus Pulled Up and Parked, Obstructing Our View of the Sky’
description: Stargazing in Fort Tryon Park, leading a tour group and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘Happy Birthday Doug.’ Here’s a Vodka Stinger.
description: Drew Droege’s solo show is a laugh-out-loud funny social sendup, but it doesn’t add up to more than a series of vignettes.
content: Drew Droege’s new solo show — “Happy Birthday Doug,” at SoHo Playhouse — is packed with killer lines. Last Friday, people in the audience laughed pretty much nonstop. Yet it’s not all that funny on the page. What elevates the text is Droege’s supercharged performance as he brings to life a handful of the gay men attending Doug’s 41st birthday party at a Los Angeles wine bar. A simple “hello” becomes an elongated growl filled with sarcasm and a pinch of contempt. “Bitch” is a simultaneous attack and exclamation point. It can be glorious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: ‘Sonic the Hedgehog’ Opens Strong at the Box Office
description: The movie’s creators redesigned its title character after an early trailer was ridiculed. That may have helped it avoid disaster.
content: “Sonic the Hedgehog” shot to the top of the box office this weekend, opening to an estimated $57 million in domestic ticket sales — a somewhat unlikely success story for the film, an adaptation of a video game series about a little blue creature with a superhuman sprint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Kingsbury
title: My Friend Lives Inside the War on Terror. Listen to Him.
description: Capt. Richard Murphy spoke to me about his looming deployment to Afghanistan and how he keeps soldiers mentally healthy.
content: Outside the headquarters of the Army’s 10th Mountain Division at Fort Drum stands a monument to the unit, the one most frequently deployed in the years since the attacks of 9/11. Two wiry soldiers, frozen in bronze, help each other ascend a crag with the help of a rope. Etched around the monument is the unit’s motto: “Climb to Glory.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: As Floods Spread in Mississippi, Officials Say the Worst Is Still Ahead
description: Heavy rains swamped a reservoir and pushed the Pearl River over its banks, forcing evacuations. The river may not crest until Monday.
content: FLOWOOD, Miss. — The authorities in charge of the dam that regulates the flow of water from a sprawling reservoir into the Pearl River strained to hold off the inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Tessa Majors: What We Know About the 14-Year-Old Charged With Murder
description: The authorities have accused Rashaun Weaver of fatally stabbing the Barnard student during a robbery near the college in December.
content: “Help me, I’m being robbed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: America Dominates Olympic Basketball, but What About ‘3x3’?
description: Team U.S.A. is set to select its three-on-three team for the Tokyo Olympics. Will the rest of the world have a fighting chance in this version of the sport?
content: The candidates for the American men’s Olympic team for three-on-three basketball include an investment banker, a social worker and a podcaster. There are former college players from Princeton and Florida Southern, many of them following something like the supposedly outdated amateur model of 50 years ago to claim Olympic glory in an event that will make its debut at the Games this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Kicks Off the Daytona 500, and a Race for Florida Votes
description: The appearance at the NASCAR event, complete with flyovers and a trip around the track in the presidential limousine, was a highly choreographed showing by the president.
content: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — President Trump put his showmanship skills on full display on Sunday at the Daytona International Speedway, leading the famous stock car drivers in a lap around the 2.5-mile racetrack. A sold-out crowd of 101,500 people cheered his appearance in a state he must win this year to secure re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Former Justice Dept. Lawyers Press for Barr to Step Down
description: More than 1,100 former prosecutors and officials who served in Republican and Democratic administrations signed an open letter condemning the president and the attorney general over the Stone case.
content: WASHINGTON — More than 1,100 former federal prosecutors and Justice Department officials called on Attorney General William P. Barr on Sunday to step down after he intervened last week to lower the Justice Department’s sentencing recommendation for President Trump’s longtime friend Roger J. Stone Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Trip Gabriel
title: Democrats Look Ahead From Nevada and See a Common Enemy: Bloomberg
description: The presidential candidates worked to sell their pitches to the state’s caucusgoers on Sunday, but also ripped into the billionaire they will soon face in the Super Tuesday contests on March 3.
content: LAS VEGAS — The Democratic presidential candidates raced on Sunday to make the most of their final weekend day before the Nevada caucuses, selling their messages and tearing into their opponents.
source.name: The New York Times
